comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: Wow. Does that still exist? Why yes it does. It's like something out of Camberwick Green. And I've found out a small bit about it. Fort Hill Gardens is a hilltop town park on the site of a 17th-century fort, opened in 1846. Features include a column with a statue of about 1845-7 and a bandstand with a clock tower of 1895.

comment.author: 72025404@N08
comment._content: lovely image!

comment.author: 58930216@N04
comment._content: It's a lovely walk around Fort Hill, great views to be had of the town....

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] Excellent, so this is definitely post-1895 then! And do you reckon the "large embossed head" is of Mr Thomas Plunkett, Chairman of the Town Commissioners?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 38915126@N06
comment._content: Great image and capture.

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: I think it might well be Thomas Plunkett himself up there. Here's the inscription below the portrait. "Erected by Public subscription in grateful appreciation of the services rendered to the town by Thomas Plunkett. M.R.I.A. who during his chairmanship of the Town Commissioners 1882 to 1885 and 1888 to 1894 transformed and beautified these grounds and carried out many other improvements for the promotion of the health and comfort of the community. A.D.1895" Someone else on Flickr has a photo of it, and it's almost 4 o'clock.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] Brilliant! Adding the inscription to the description above. And spooky about the 4 o'clock...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 54059458@N02
comment._content: Bandstands seemed to be the rage in the late 1800's. Enniskillen Bandstand www.scottishironwork.org/catdetail.asp?ironid=28890 Nairn Bandstand www.scottishironwork.org/catdetail.asp?ironid=173

comment.author: 58930216@N04
comment._content: Lots of bandstands everywhere all across the UK & Ireland, all looking pretty much the same design, maybe made by the same companies?

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: It was manufactured by Walter Macfarlane & Co at the Saracen Foundry Glasgow.

comment.author: 74989785@N02
comment._content: owmmm...so beautiful

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: What a fabulous bandstand and clock. Described as "probably unique" here - www.scottishironwork.org/catdetail.asp?ironid=28890 . I wonder how they wound the clock? The children look like they are about to be beamed up, or worse still, about to break into a chorus from the 'Sound of Music'.

comment.author: 40708286@N07
comment._content: Looking at the body language and the expressions they have all been asked not to move. Some just can't keep still lol

comment._content: Marvelous!!!!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Good question from [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia]. How did they wind the clock? Presumably it was mechanically operated, but it would still have needed to be changed twice yearly, or did they have summer and wintertime hour changes back in the 1890s?
